text: (upbeat music)
- My name is Henry.

I'm an inside sales rep
out of Vancouver, Canada.
So I've been at AWS for about nine months.

What I found most striking
as an experience ,
coming from sales at other organizations,

is the ability to be able
to actually think backwards
from the customer.
What are the customers needs?
What are our customers' customers' needs?
And then that truly enables us

to be able to sit with
the customer at the table
and be a true consultant.
You know, for the first time,

like, I felt like I could
actually be supported
by my sales organization at AWS

to truly understand what the
customers are looking for

and what they need, and
potentially the things
that they don't even know they needed.
Prior to coming to AWS,
one of the things that I'd been told
by my peers in the industry is that,

you know, it's one of those
companies that's very rigid.

It's got, you know, these
leadership principles

that causes you to have
to work in this framework
where you can't really bend the rules.
And that's totally, exactly the opposite
of what I've experienced.

When I think about the
leadership principles at AWS,

it's all about kind of
this foundational thinking
that enables us to operate as a team
with less ambiguity, right?
So leadership principles
such as learn and be curious, right.
Really try to adopt the idea

that we're always trying
to learn from one another
and from our customers.
Bias for action. Let's take action, right?

Let's not worry about the
consequences all the time.
Let's focus on speed, agility,

and helping our customers
move quick as well.

If you're looking for a sales
job at any tech company,
there's no better place than at AWS
where you can truly be thinking big

while being able to operate
like you work at a startup.
You can be nimble.

You have the support of
a large organization,
from the technology staff that AWS offers

to a team that really
supports you to be able
to drive big outcomes for customers.
(upbeat music)
